result.execSummary:
The defendant Zachary K. Tepsa was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Delivery of Methamphetamine [Modifiers: Repeater, Second and Subsequent Offense], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
If Probation or Extended Supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
150 days sentence credit if revoked from probation.

miscConds.notes: PAYABLE DIRECTLY TO AND COLLECTED BY EAU CLAIRE COUNTY CLERK OF COURT.  NOT A CONDITION OF PROBATION.
Obtain/maintain full-time schedule of work and/or school.

Comply with any conditions/programming per agent.
Participate in and successfully complete Drug Court program.
Provide DNA sample and pay fee if not already given.
Undergo AODA assessment and follow-through with recommendations.

stayed for use at discretion of Drug Court team.

Granting Motion to Terminate (Absconding/Probation Revocation/Incarceration in another jurisdiction) and Administrative Transfer Out of Treatment Court

Administrative Transfer to Treatment Court
IT IS ORDERED This case is transferred to Eau Claire County Circuit Court Branch 2 while defendant is a participant in the Treatment Court program. the case will be administratively reassigned back to the initial court upon defendant's successful completion of the Eau Claire County Treatment Court Program, or upon defendant's termination from that program.
